title: Can a car’s windshield crack without any sort of impact? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes. It can happen because of body flex or from extremes of hot or cold but it’s usually from an impact. I’ve inspected 100’s of windshields for this over the years and I don’t remember ever finding one that didn’t have an impact. They can be very hard to see, I usually felt them and would use the tip of a ball point pen to show the customer where the original impact was, it’ll drop right into the divit even if it’s hard to see.

Yes. Rapid condensation. If the glass is REALLY hot, like when the temperature is very high, the windows are all rolled up tight, and the sun is blazing on the glass; then, the glass temperature can reach as high as 170 F. At that moment, if cold rain falling from high altitude suddenly wets the glass; it can literally explode out of the car. Though it is EXTREMELY rare, I have seen it happen. More likely would be just a long single crack from side to side or from top to bottom.

Yes. Just wait til it's -40 degrees outside, then start and fully warm up your engine. Forget to turn the blower on for heat while it's warming up. Then wait until you go out to the truck, and your buddy says “Holy shit, it's still freezing in here!”, and then turns the defroster on full blast…my good friend put six long cracks in the windshield of our old ranch truck doing just that.

Yes. Boil a kettle full of water and pour it on the windscreen to remove the ice on a very cold morning. Crack. (PS, i’m not the one who did it, it was someone I worked with.) most cracks are impact related. When I get a customer complain about the screen cracking ‘for no reason’ ans wanting it replaced under warranty I run a ball-point pen along the crack. ‘Tick.’ they can hear and feel for them self the impact point.

Yes. Many years ago a pheasant flew into the windshield of my MGA. I took it to the dealer who installed a new one. I hd to fly out of town and upon my return found the windshield with a big crack through the center. The “technician” had installed the new windshield with the foam rubber sealer bunched up in one spot, putting the glass under stress. The hot sun then shining on that glass was enough to cause it to snap without “any sort of impact”!

Yes and it happens all the time. Any stress placed on a pane of glass can cause a crack. Things like uneven heating, bending or twisting of the pane from stresses on the chassis. Even a slight nick along the edge of a pane can lead to cracking so keep your hard tools away from it.

Yes. People used to wake up to a iced up windscreen in the winter and think ‘you know what, I’ll just melt the ice with hot water from my kettle’. One rapid expansion and thermal shock later…. I would like to think this doesn’t happen anymore, but I bet word hasn’t gotten around yet.

I had a small, vertical crack from not getting my windshield wipers off in time when I went through a car wash. Sealed the crack. Years later during a hard freeze, that crack spread across my entire windshield. Bill
if the body twists the glass can crack but that is rare.
